There is some hedge fund in the dark shorting the NHL and trying to drive it out of business. There is almost a TV blackout of playoff games, ESPN devotes as much time to cricket in Pakistan as it does to hockey, the NHL has staffed their PR and media teams with the worst staff imaginable (have you gone to websites of the teams?)

The NHL has $200 million a year in TV broadcast fees compared to the NBA's $980 million, Gary Bettman remains the commissioner after 3 lockouts, there has to be something trying to sink this league...

(http://qzprod.files.wordpress.com/2014/05/average-annual-fees-from-us-tv...

TMA-1, I agree ... and while the league is out to lunch when it comes to marketing, the "dark force" behind this is espn. I have noticed one of the talking points consistently spewed across several of espn's shows is that hockey is no longer one of the four major sports ... apparently, the reason for this is that they no longer carry the NHL (they even try to position nascar as a major "sport" which is laughable, but understandable, since they do televise it). Like it's said, you repeat a lie long enough ...

It is infinitely disappointing. though, that the Times has fallen victim to this same thinking.

The reason hockey is sliding off the pages of the NY Times is called football. We know it as soccer here but football is being foisted on the US viewing public as a major sport in this country (it is but it hasn't earned pushing hockey off the front pages of the New York press).
What does it take to make the front page of this web site?  If any other NY sports team won an important playoff game, they would have merited the coverage.

Certainly, all those "conservatives" who sing the peans about  reading the Constitution literally -- according to the actual words of the Constitution -- need to be reminded that calling a corporation a "person" is a travesty -- a complete legal fiction. Ditto for the Declaration of Independence -- which many "conservatives" often confuse with the Constitution.

Agreed.

Like the hedge fund managers who similarly abuse the privilege of American citizenship by cheating the taxman (and thereby the country that enables their prosperity), these corporations should be seen as abandoning the nation to which they owe their success. As a foreign pharma company, Pfizer should lose the right to thrive in our "retail" healthcare marketplace of vastly inflated prices, which they claim is necessary to recover drug R&D. Let's see the US government - through Medicare, Obamacare or any other bloody "care" - hammer the prices down (as they are in every other global market). Those are real market forces - why not secure the lowest prices for our citizens?

Pfizer will find considerably less profits to shelter from London, will choke off their R&D pipeline and will watch their share price plummet. Tax rate differentials will be the least of their woes.

Or - shareholders could figure this out now, see through the stupid "inversion" scheme and find new leaders to actually grow the company.

Brilliant!

Reading this article, I'm struck by the thought - can we stop with the illusion that corporations are 'persons' now? Clearly the multinationals have no country, feel no citizenship beyond the green flag of profits, profits, profits, above all else. So giving American corporations the same rights as American citizens, without demanding the same duties of citizenship and American 'personhood' is just wrong. Since these companies evidence no loyalty to the USA, we should strip them of all the privileges of American 'personhood' and treat them as any foreign business, subject to the taxes and laws of this country, but not entitled to participate in our elections or influence our government... after all, they aren't behaving like good citizens, rather more like traitors.

American women have killed 56 million fetuses since Roe v Wade. Do you really want to kill 56 million Pakistani fetuses? Is that where the future of Pakistani women lies? "Reading, writing and killing"?

We should listen more to Gandhi and to Rumi and to Kabir than we do to the four liberal justices on the Supreme Court. But I don't know if you progressives will understand.

Mr. Obama spied on the leaders of Germany and Brazil, both of whom are women. Is THAT your idea of respect for women?

Read Emily Dickinson. Read Michael Tomasello. Listen to Mirabai from your own state of Rajasthan. Maybe then you will understand that life contains music, love, beauty, and that these are the things which matter. Republicans do not understand these things. But neither do you.

R36, While gladly sharing your humanistic concerns, as also the enlightening references to Gandhi, Rumi, Labor and Mira, but beg to differ on the women's reproductive rights and personal freedoms, which they have gained after a long struggle, and should be respected by society. Thanks.

" women's reproductive rights and personal freedoms,"

This is not actually a black and white issue because more than one party is involved and all have rights.

I have zero sympathy with those Republicans who object to abortion in case of rape, or who object to certain forms of contraception.

But at the other extreme is your old master, the UK which allows abortion for all nine months in case the fetus has a club foot or cleft palate, both of which are treatable conditions. Is it OK to kill a nine month old fetus merely because it has a cleft palate? Try and think about this problem outside the box of "women's reproductive rights."

When more than one party is involved, to talk about the rights of just one party is a form of injustice. I believe it was Gandhi who said that a solution which does not address the concerns of all parties is not just.

So the question is not abortion or no abortion, but rather abortion WHEN? And for WHAT reason? It is terrible that educated people like you take an oversimplified position on an issue which is very far from being black and white.

This is only partially relevant but Sweden, which is the most progressive country in Europe, also has the highest rate of rape. And according to Mr. Obama, one in five female college students in the US is sexually assaulted. So think before blindly imitating the West! They do NOT know all the answers.

Prior to thinking about liberation of girls through modern educational tools, the most important task seems to be to first liberate the society and state from the stranglehold of the forces of social conservatism, religious obscurantism, and terror, so that conducive social environment could be created to effect a commensurate attitudinal change in the centuries old patriarchal social order common to the Indian sub-continent.

Please elucidate the distinction between "Islamic" and Muslim. As someone who has seen this very moving and disturbing film, I find that the most accurate perception in the review is the line that says it's about "a society steeped in a deadly machismo." This deadly machismo which encompasses everything from casual male rape among boys, to the total inaccessibility of women in normal ways, comes directly from the way Islam is interpreted and practiced throughout much of the Islamic world. This film -- and many an analysis of the troubles in associated with Islamic practice  -- never bothers to ask what might be different if women were granted full and equal human rights.  Perhaps machismo would be neither so deadly nor so inevitable.

There is no way that killing civilians is "Islamic" any more than it is "Christian" but sad to say some Christians and some Muslims have done such deeds. Terminology aside, films and literature can help get us into the heads of those deluded in this way. Evil is indeed often banal but also human. Tragically it is everywhere.

We accepted some free tickets and saw "Legends" last weekend. Given the tepid reviews, it wouldn't have been our choice of movie, but we had a nice surprise. The character development and music were both great. It was one of those movies that although geared to kids, had some appeal for adults too. . . The animation was great, although I'm told that it works better in 2D rather than 3D for some reason.

We usually rely pretty heavily on NYT reviews in making our viewing choices and for the most part, they are spot on. Please give this little gem another look.

This may work to Google's advantage relative to smaller companies or non-profits where compliance will likely be more burdensome to implement.

In any case we know the NSA will keep all this information, continuing to operate in their own extra-legal zone.

I don't understand why this ruling applies to the search engines and not to the actual sources of the data on the web. If the availability of such information is bad, then why should the sites hosting it (such as government and media sites) be allowed to publicly expose it?

Should this newspaper be allowed to report that in 1998 Señor Costeja had financial problems and a bankruptcy as part of this article? How is that any different? Should it now be filtered out of google news reporting because of that?

This is the new Angst, isn´t it? To give up the rights of many in order to catch the few perpetrators. Every nation has elaborate systems to seek out and deal with criminals. General communication - like e.g. public transport  - must not be a regular means of policing! Otherwise you change from a free society into a controlled one. And from there it would be a very, very small step to a "well meaning", politically correct dictatorship of the "good and righteous". Sponteneity and creativity would decline and "normality" would reign everything. Something that is much more european than american at the moment. And what this EU-ruling is trying to change, actually. So, yes, you could understand this decision as forward thinking.

To echo:  who you refer to is only a subset of people who are written about on the internet.  Since most people believe what they read on the internet (and in newspapers) and many more people are maligned than the "oppressed fraudsters, war criminals, child molesters, et. al"., the forward thinking European decision will help people whose reputations are horribly besmirched. Also, it is unlikely that the "war criminals" etc would take the time to expunge their google publicity. As was said a long time ago, people in glass houses shouldn't throw stones!
Who'd have thought someone is finally looking out for oppressed fraudsters, war criminals,  child molesters, et al. Those Europeans are so forward thinking.

The media can and should rely on solid sources such as court records and the public information the government has to publish.

There is a whole new industry that is growing whose sole purpose is cleaning up one's reputation online. For many business owners, that is an added cost of doing business in an age of Yelp reviews, many of which are written by people who were paid by some unknown party to write, and not only disgruntled customers. Of course, there are no regulations to protect a business or service provider, or a customer, from a bad review, or an undeserved good review. There are other examples...

Free Speech should not include paid-for lies and semi-truths. How did the world manage to function before the internet? Does anyone remember?
